ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A survey of European history during the Middle Ages.
I learned how to better analyze my primary resources to write critically about them.
Key events in European history from 1000-1500.
Informative survey course about medieval Europe, historiographical frameworks, theories to approaching history, drawing conclusions where evidence/time/events might not be immediately obvious.

This course spans 500 years, so you will gain a broad understanding of the period and key themes and issues.  Section involves a lot of primary source analysis, so you will get better at analysing sources from the period and using them in essays.
Gained insight into high-late medieval Europe.  Enjoyed learning about an era that pervades world History and popular culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very interesting, but I wish more information was on the slides to better follow virtually.

I think the professor made class very engaging, the primary sources were fun to read (and closely reading them in section was fun). My only comment might be its hard to keep track of all the material because the professor talks quickly, so perhaps a terms sheet, or access to the PowerPoint before lecture would help with note taking.

The lectures were engaging, although it was sometimes hard to keep track of all the new knowledge as we covered such a large time period so quickly and went thematically rather than chronologically.  Professor Bezerra is a great lecturer and will keep you interested even in the topics you may not think you would like as much!

Strengths:  The content is very interesting and fun to learn about.
Weaknesses:  Lectures move very slowly and are at times quite hard to follow.  I ended up watching the recorded lectures on 2x speed because the live lectures were too slow.
the weaknesses of this course lie in how fast we go through the content

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the slides could have had a little more information, and also a little bit of historical background communicated. The professor did an excellent job of making the lectures interesting.
Recording the lectures helped for study purposes.
Lectures could be quicker and better organized.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think that this course was very interesting and allows you to succeed.
Yes-the Professor I think works hard to make the material accessible and the workload is reasonable.
Yes especially if you love medieval history
Yes! If you're interested in learning about the period, but don't want to delve too deeply into any single topic it is definitely a good choice!

I would recommend this to any student who is interested in medieval history.  It is an area that I've heard so much about in popular culture and stories throughout my life (knights and castles and Crusades), yet not gotten an actual historic look into--this course filled that void very well.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Discussion section weekly.
Also with live virtual discussion section.
Weekly virtual discussion sections

virtual lecture 
virtual discussion sections
